title: The Careful Use of Compliments
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: She drove out of Comrie, back along the road by which she had entered the village, and away in the direction of Glenartney.

title: The Careful Use of Compliments
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: And then the road began to dip down towards Glenartney and the River Earn, and Comrie was before her, grey-slate roofs among trees, small white-gabled houses, a village typical of that part of Scotland – well ordered, quiet, a place where nothing much may happen, but where that suited the inhabitants well enough.

title: The Careful Use of Compliments
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: Now, as she turned on to the road that led from the village of Braco across the hills to Comrie, her anticipation over her meeting with McInnes increased – if there was to be a meeting, she reminded herself.

title: The Careful Use of Compliments
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: It would take her an hour and a half to reach Comrie by the back road past Braco, and she decided that she would  enjoy  the  journey.

title: The works of Professor Wilson of the University of Edinburgh,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: No eclipse set down for to-day — the old earthquake dwells in the neighbourhood of Comrie, and has never been known to journey thus far north — besides, he has for some years been bed-ridden ; argal, there is about to be a storm.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: Wepassed by Sir D. Dundas's place, Dunira, beforewe changed horses at Comrie, for the last time,and then by Mr. Williams's, and by Ochtertyre,Sir W. Keith Murray's.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns :
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: Tuesday morning, [28M Aug.'\ Breakfast with Captain  Forrester— leave Stirling— Ochil Hills— Devon River— Forth and Teith— Allan River— Strathallan, a fine country but little improven — Ardoch Camp — Cross Earn to Crieflf— Dine, and go to Arbruchil ; cold reception  at Arbruchil — A most romantically pleasant ride up Earn, by Auchertyre and Comrie — Sup at Crieflf.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns:
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: and Tieth — Allan River — Strathallan, a fine country, but little improved — Cross Earn to Criefi" — Dine and go to Arbruchil — cold reception at Arbruchil — a most romantically pleasant ride up Earn, by Auchtertyre and Comrie to Arbruchil  — Sup at Crieff.

title: Journal of a tour through the Highlands of Scotland during the summer of MDCCCXXIX.
author: Botfield, Beriah
snippet: This vaUey burst gloriously on our view ;Lord MelvUle's granite pillar, on Dunmore, forming the centre of a lovely picture of the rugged andcloud-capt Grampian mountains, at the foot ofwhich crouched the groves and lawns of Lawers,Duneira, &c. ; and stiU lower the town of Comrie,which, after our descent from the hiUs, we approached by the plain of Dalginross.

title: Story of Maurice Lestrange. Being an account of his travels and adventures in Scotland during the year 1765. [A tale.]
author: Omond, George William Thomson.
snippet: I recollect,one time, Sandy and I were sitting on the top of thedyke, in our Sunday best, w-hen the old schoolmasterfrom Comrie came staggering along, and we burst outlaughing.

title: Braes o' Balquhidder. A novel
author: Aytoun, Douglas.
snippet: Being the highest of the Grampian range, the prospectis at once commanding and fraught with revelations—the Strath of the Earn, St. Fillans, Comrie, Crieff, Ardvoirlich, Glen Artney, and innumerable points of intereston every side.
